metadata.title: Robinson R22
aws::graph::propositions: A floor-mounted, foot-activated push-to-talk switch facilitates intercom communications for the left-seat occupant in the Robinson R22.
Some later models of the Robinson R22 may be equipped with a voice-activated intercom system.
The Robinson R22 helicopter rotor system consists of a two-bladed main rotor.
The Robinson R22 helicopter rotor system consists of a two-bladed antitorque rotor on the tail.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with a teetering hinge.
The antitorque rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with a teetering hinge.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 rotates with the starboard (right) side blade moving forward.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with two coning hinges.
Collective pitch inputs to the main rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through pushrods.
Cyclic pitch inputs to the main rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through pushrods.
The Robinson R22 uses a conventional swashplate mechanism for transmitting pitch inputs to the main rotor.
Control inputs to the tail rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through a single pushrod inside the aluminum tail cone.
The Robinson R22 has a mechanical throttle correlator that adjusts the throttle as the collective pitch control is raised or lowered.
The mechanical throttle correlator in the Robinson R22 eases the pilot's workload.
The pilot of the Robinson R22 needs to make only small adjustments by twisting the throttle grip on the collective throughout the flight regime.

statements.value: A floor-mounted, foot-activated push-to-talk switch facilitates intercom communications for the left-seat occupant in the Robinson R22.
Some later models of the Robinson R22 may be equipped with a voice-activated intercom system.
The Robinson R22 helicopter rotor system consists of a two-bladed main rotor.
The Robinson R22 helicopter rotor system consists of a two-bladed antitorque rotor on the tail.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with a teetering hinge.
The antitorque rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with a teetering hinge.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 rotates with the starboard (right) side blade moving forward.
The main rotor of the Robinson R22 is equipped with two coning hinges.
Collective pitch inputs to the main rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through pushrods.
Cyclic pitch inputs to the main rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through pushrods.
The Robinson R22 uses a conventional swashplate mechanism for transmitting pitch inputs to the main rotor.
Control inputs to the tail rotor of the Robinson R22 are transmitted through a single pushrod inside the aluminum tail cone.
The Robinson R22 has a mechanical throttle correlator that adjusts the throttle as the collective pitch control is raised or lowered.
The mechanical throttle correlator in the Robinson R22 eases the pilot's workload.
The pilot of the Robinson R22 needs to make only small adjustments by twisting the throttle grip on the collective throughout the flight regime.

text:
A floor-mounted, foot-activated push-to-talk switch facilitates intercom communications for the left-seat occupant, although some later models may be equipped with a voice-activated intercom system.
The helicopter rotor system consists of a two-bladed main rotor and two-bladed antitorque rotor on the tail, each equipped with a teetering hinge. The main rotor rotates with the starboard (right) side blade moving forward. The main rotor is also equipped with two coning hinges. Collective and cyclic pitch inputs to the main rotor are transmitted through pushrods and a conventional swashplate mechanism. Control inputs to the tail rotor are transmitted through a single pushrod inside the aluminum tail cone.
To ease the pilot's workload, a mechanical throttle correlator adjusts the throttle as the collective pitch control is raised or lowered.  The pilot needs to make only small adjustments by twisting the throttle grip on the collective throughout the flight regime.
